Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love you, love you
 Love

The repetition of this line can refer to the number of times they gave love to a person, but it could also be a gesture to the fans who have been on this journey with them.

It could also be a conscious nod towards the fact that The Beatles used the word “Love” more than 600 times in their career, and love and good vibes were part of many of their songs, particularly in their early years.

Careful listening at this point reveals the pitch of the song changes slightly, with McCartney’s piano sounding slightly flat – possibly a side-effect of overdubbing the guitar solos.

John Lennon wasn’t generally happy with the work that was being done on Abbey Road and at one point wanted to have his songs on separate sides from Paul’s.

That’s Paul again, the unfinished song, right? We’re on Abbey Road. Just a piece at the end. He had a line in it [sings] ‘And in the end, the love you get is equal to the love you give [sic],’ which is a very cosmic, philosophical line. Which again proves that if he wants to, he can think.
-John Lennon

This contains the only drum solo Ringo ever performed as a Beatle. He hates solos and had to be persuaded to do it. It’s also of note that his drum track was spread in the stereo image, although it seems peculiar that the snare is panned to the far right.

Lennon, McCartney and Harrison took turns doing guitar solos. This is the only time in the Beatles' history that they did so. If you listen closely, you can hear how the styles change from one to the other. The order goes McCartney (stinging “Taxman”-style guitar), Harrison (slide guitar similar to his work on his 1970 solo album All Things Must Pass), Lennon (distorted heavy guitar like in “Revolution”) and then back again.

In the context of The End, this is the Beatles going out on top – proving themselves damn talented musicians as well as songwriters.



Here’s the times during the song each band member plays their solos:

0:20-0:34  Ringo
0:53-0:57  Paul
0:57-1:02  George
1:02-1:04  John
1:05-1:09  Paul
1:09-1:13  George
1:13-1:17  John
1:17-1:21  Paul
1:21-1:24  George
1:25-1:28  John

Oh yeah, alright
 Are you going to be in my dreams
 Tonight?

This song is a farewell from the band, that had its worst moments during the “Get Back sessions” earlier the same year. The band got back in the studios to remember how they used to be on the recordings and it went with no further problems.



“Are you gonna be in my dreams tonight” – a simple rhyme to the senseless “Oh yeah, alright”, words that symbolize rock and roll.

And in the end
 The love you take
 Is equal to the love you make

Essentially, The Beatles' closing statement. It was intended as the last lyric on Abbey Road, the last album they recorded. Let It Be was the last album they released, but it was recorded earlier.



It’s the end of the band and they knew it, though it wasn’t spoken. The love they collected from everybody was the same intense love that they invested in the band’s work. It’s their last message of love.

Musically, this last section goes from a sad and poignant A minor to a safe and happy C major, suggesting that despite troubles and hardship, everything will be alright in the end.

And then – bam! “Her Majesty” makes a surprise, last minute appearance.
